01/08 superhero preview

Big Bang Theory
The X-movies. The Marvel Cinematic Universe. DC’s Justice League kick-off… Empire explores the future of the superhero movie: universe by universe
words: chris hewitt THE STUDIO: 20th Century Fox THE SUPERS: Wolverine, The X-Men, Deadpool, Gambit

That was then: Simon Kinberg, writer-producer of X-Men: Days Of Future Past, talking to Empire a couple of months before that movie’s release, says, “There’s no question everybody admires the Marvel model, the way it built into and out of Avengers. It’s something we think about a lot.”

1 Take A Cut Of The Profits To play the title role in the 1911 Australian film Sweet Nell Of Old Drury, Aussie stage legend Nellie Stewart agreed a fee of £1,000 plus a share of the profits, the first recorded instance of a film star getting a cut of the points. Sly’s Rocky(s), Jack’s Joker, Tom’s Missions and the rest were decades away.

D’OH! Donald Sutherland is said to have lost out on $20 million of Animal House profits by instead sticking with his $50,000 fee.

2 Trust Your Casting Instincts. The studio thought he was “a shrimp, funny looking, not attractive”. Producer Robert Evans wanted “anyone but [him]” and watched Francis Coppola test “every actor who had an O at the end of his name”. But Coppola refused to budge on Al Pacino as Michael Corleone in The Godfather. Genius and riches ensued.

D’OH! Robert De Niro was cast in the small role of Corleone hood Paulie. If a bigger, better job hadn’t caused him to pull out, he couldn’t have been in Part II...

3 Go West. In 1911, execs at the Centaur Film Company of New Jersey decided they should relocate. Al Christie chose California, David Horsley favoured Florida. They tossed for it, Cali won, and they rented a former bar on Sunset Boulevard for $40 a month. In October that year, the renamed Nestor Film Company became Hollywood’s first studio.

D’OH! In 2002, construction of the South West Film Studios began in St. Agnes, Cornwall. In 2004, the former MD was convicted of forgery. The incomplete lot was mothballed in 2006. No films, ever.

NEW UNIVERSES?

Empire selects the coolest comic-book properties that we’d most like to see given the movie treatment.

Words Helen O’Hara

Iron Man - 2008

Director Jon Favreau
Players Robert Downey Jr., Samuel L. Jackson

Tony Stark returns home to discover Samuel L. Jackson as Nick Fury, director of S.H.I.E.L.D., who wants him in on a little thing called the “Avengers Initiative”. Jackson was smuggled onto set in complete secrecy. Naturally, news of his cameo leaked everywhere. We blame Hydra spies.

Sets up Avengers Assemble. Right from the off.

Captain America: The First Avenger - 2011

Director Joss Whedon
Players Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans,

Mark Ruffalo, Chris Hemsworth, Scarlett Johansson, Samuel L. Jackson The only movie that doesn’t have a custom-made tag, instead The First Avenger concludes with a brief trailer for Avengers Assemble, which was in production at that time.

Sets up Take a guess...

Thor: The Dark World - 2013

Director James Gunn
Players Benicio Del Toro, Ophelia Lovibond, Ray Stevenson, Jaimie AlexanderAsgardians Sif (Alexander) and Volstagg (Stevenson) take the incredibly powerful Aether (Infinity Stone #3) to Knowhere and entrust it to The Collector, a wildly overacting Benicio Del Toro.

Sets up Guardians Of The Galaxy.

Prototype Gremlin Puppet

Gremlins 2: The New Batch (1990)

“Originally they asked me to do [Gremlins 2] and I wasn’t that interested. Chris Walas had done the original and I didn’t just want to reproduce somebody else’s designs. They said, ‘What can we do to make you interested?’ I wanted to redesign the gremlins and the mogwai. I really wanted to make them individuals. The decisions they made on the original were right for that film, but I wanted to contribute ideas too. So we came up with the idea of the genetic lab where we could mutate the gremlins and have the vegetable gremlin and the spider gremlin and so on. Then it became much more appealing to me, to change Chris’ designs and do Rick Baker versions of them. It would be CG these days, but there is a certain charm to having something real, and you have to think cleverly about how you’re going to achieve all these different things.”

Estimated sale price: $1,000-$1,500

THE JUDGE AND RUSTY THE DOG CONCEPT ART

The Frighteners (1996)

“This came about because I once went to a film festival in Spain... The person sitting next to me was this fan-boy who recognised me... and it was Peter Jackson. He was showing Braindead. Fran (Walsh) was there and I just really liked them. We became fast friends. When The Frighteners came along he asked me to do the Judge make-up. He was talking about moving to Los Angeles. I said, ‘In New Zealand you’re so far away from the studios you can make the movies you want to make. If you come to Los Angeles, you’re going to have executives telling you what to do. I’d stay in the land where you’re a king.’”

Estimated sale price: $400-$600

HELLBOY LIFE-SIZE MAKE-UP DESIGN MAQUETTE

Hellboy (2004)

“I often seem to get stuck with taking a well-known thing that exists already as a two-dimensional drawing and turning it into something that works practically. That’s always a scary thing. Guillermo (del Toro) contacted us before he had a deal. Frankly, I was not familiar with Hellboy at all, but Guillermo gave me some of the comics and I thought he was kind of cool. He wanted Ron Perlman, but knew he was going to run into some resistance. They would want whoever the hot new star was. But I knew Ron from Beauty And The Beast and thought he would be perfect for Hellboy. So just on spec we did some designs that helped get the movie made. It’s really nice to work with someone like Guillermo, who at least will give you an answer… Not that I always agree with it (laughs)!”

Estimated sale price: $600-$800
